markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

orlandosentinel.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of a daily newspaper serving Orlando, Florida, and other parts of central Florida.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The Orlando Sentinel is owned by Tribune Publishing Company, a publicly traded, Chicago-based media and publishing company formerly known as Tronc Inc. Tribune owns newspapers and publications in major markets, including The Baltimore Sun, New York Daily News, and its flagship publication, the Chicago Tribune.

Tribune generates its revenue through advertising and subscriptions for its printed and digital products. Its publications have won numerous awards, including a Pulitzer Prize in 2017.

Content

The Sentinel provides coverage of five central Florida counties, reporting on local and state news as well as politics and education. It covers news about Orlando’s tourism industry. The Entertainment section of orlandosentinel.com features stories and reviews of theater and art exhibitions, along with guides detailing entertainment in area neighborhoods. The site features podcasts such as College Gridiron 365, which covers college sports in Florida, and Orlando Sentinel Conversations, “a podcast about what makes Central Florida tick.” The Associated Press provides much of the Sentinel’s national news reporting.

The website features a separate hurricane section, which covers tropical weather in the region. There is also a Spanish-language version of its content.

Credibility

The paper’s reporting staff handles most of the content. Articles and headlines are straightforward and factual. The website attributes all photographs and frequently runs corrections and clarifications. The Sentinel also provides a detailed ethics policy outlining its commitment to accuracy, fairness, and transparency. News and opinion sections on the website are clearly distinguished. Letters to the editor, published on the website, regularly include multiple perspectives, including those critical of the Sentinel.

The Sentinel is a three-time winner of the Pulitzer Prize. The paper won its most recent Pulitzer in 2000 for editorial writing that exposed predatory lending practices in the state, which led to a change in local lending regulations. It was a Pulitzer finalist, and winner of other awards, for breaking news coverage of the 2016 Pulse nightclub massacre in Orlando.

Transparency

Orlandosentinel.com names authors of its content and provides information about them. The website also discloses its ownership in an About Us section, and provides a list of the publication’s editorial and senior staff. Readers can contact Sentinel staff by email and connect with them on social media. Advertising is distinguishable from editorial content.

History

The newspaper dates to 1876, when it was published as the Orange County Reporter. The Tribune Company bought the paper in 1965. In 1982, the paper was renamed, and Orlandosentinel.com launched in 1996.

Written by:
Evan Haddad

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Jim Warren
